From: Denise Burley <Denise.Burley@mohavecounty.us>
Sent: Tuesday, May 26, 2020
To: Stacy Klippenstein <SKlippenstein@mohave.edu>
Subject: Nursing students Importance:
High Stacy – We are looking for nursing students that could assist with our COVID-19 response (swabbing, data entry of testing information, etc.).
Would MCC have any resources of this nature that we could tap into?
Thank you.
Denise Denise Burley M. Admin.
CPM Health Director Mohave County Department of Public Health 700 W. Beale Street P.O. Box 7000 Kingman, AZ 86402 Kingman, AZ 86402

content: Tech Valley Drive 31 Tech Valley Drive East Greenbush, NY 12061 SOC@cisecurity.org - 1-866-787-4722 COVID-19 - Worldwide - Situation Report - 05-27-20 (Update 87) | (INC10276272)
Critical Infrastructure Involved: Energy (Oil and Natural Gas), Food and Agriculture, Government Facilities, Healthcare and Public Health, Transportation Systems (Aviation)
Summary:
The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) continues to monitor the evolving Coronavirus Disease, also known as COVID-19, situation closely.

CISA is taking part in interagency and industry coordination calls and working with critical infrastructure partners to prepare for possible disruptions to critical infrastructure that may stem from widespread illness.
FEMA reports approximately 5,304,772 (+100,264) cases and 342,029 (+4,342) deaths worldwide.
In the U.S. there are approximately 1,649,469 (+18,666) cases and 97,957 (+517) deaths.
The disparity in case numbers from previous reporting is due to FEMA citing different sources.
Key Points: · FEMA deployed 3,000 (���29) employees in support of COVID-19 response · 14,131,277 (+503,898) COVID-19 tests administered nationwide as of 26 May ·
The CDC extended the order barring non-essential travel across the US borders with Canada and Mexico until 21 June ·

The CDC announced that up to 50% of antibody tests may be incorrect CISA Actions: · Continue to conduct regular assessments of current and projected impacts to National Critical Functions based on reporting from Sector Specific Agencies, private sector partners, as well as multiple governmental and non-governmental sources of information ·

Current GETS/WPS/TSP summary: Ø Government Emergency Telecommunications (GETS) expedited: 5,770 (+5) Ø Wireless Priority Service (WPS) activated: 66,281 (+2) Ø Telecommunications Service Priority (TSP) provisioned: 314 (NC)

Respectfully, CISA Integrated Operations Coordination Center (IOCC) Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) Office: 202-282-9201 | Email: ciocc@cisa.dhs.gov Distro: CISA CV Mission Management COVID-19 SITREP 1, 2, 3 Situation Report COVID Additions CISA Region OPS CIOCC
Watch WARNING: Information in this report is FOUO//TLP: GREEN.
Recipients may only share TLP: GREEN information with peers and partner organizations within their sector or community, but not via publicly accessible channels.

This information may be circulated widely within a particular community but may not be released outside of the community, consistent with both the DHS policy relating to safeguarding FOUO information (link here) and with the Traffic Light Protocol, http://www.us-cert.gov/tlp.
Information in this report is not customarily in the public domain and may be exempt from public release under the Freedom of Information Act (5 U.S.C. �� 552).
Further, this section may contain or be based upon commercial or financial information, which is privileged or confidential, law enforcement sensitive, or deliberative/pre-decisional material.
DHS personnel are reminded of their obligations under DHS Form 11000-6, Non-Disclosure Agreement.
Further dissemination of any of the information contained in this REPORT requires express consent from the CIOCC.
TLP: GREEN UNCLASSIFIED //
FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY This message and attachments may contain confidential information.
If it appears that this message was sent to you by mistake, any retention, dissemination, distribution or copying of this message and attachments is strictly prohibited.
Please notify the sender immediately and permanently delete the message and any attachments. .....

(INC10276272).pdf FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY (TLP: GREEN)
Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Integrated Operations Division Situation Report COVID-19 - Worldwide - 05-27-20 (Update 87) | (INC10276272)
Date As Of: 05/27/2020 Sitrep Update #: 87 Incident Start Time: 02/28/2020 Incident Location:

Worldwide Incident End Time: Ongoing Impacted Sectors: Energy (Oil and Natural Gas), Food and Agriculture, Government Facilities, Healthcare and Reported Cause of Incident: COVID-19 Public Health, Transportation Systems (Aviation) Interagency Coordination: Internal and external On Scene Agencies: N/A partners Source of Information: Centers for Disease Control and Owner/Operator(s)

Involved: N/A Prevention (CDC), World Health Organization (WHO), CISA Regions, FEMA Incident Summary: The Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) continues to monitor the evolving Coronavirus Disease, also known as COVID-19, situation closely.

CISA is taking part in interagency and industry coordination calls and working with critical infrastructure partners to prepare for possible disruptions to critical infrastructure that may stem from widespread illness.
FEMA reports approximately 5,304,772 (+100,264) cases and 342,029 (+4,342) deaths worldwide.
In the U.S. there are approximately 1,649,469 (+18,666) cases and 97,957 (+517) deaths.
Key Points: •
FEMA deployed 3,000 (‐29) employees in support of COVID-19 response •
(+503,898) COVID-19 tests administered nationwide as of 26 May •
The CDC extended the order barring non-essential travel across the US borders with Canada and Mexico until 21 June •

The CDC announced that up to 50% of antibody tests may be incorrect CRITICAL INFRASTRUCTURE IMPACTS ENERGY (Oil) More than 240 US oil and gas companies may be forced to file for bankruptcy protection during the next 2 years if oil prices remain low.
(Natural Gas)

US liquified natural gas producers continue to face worldwide order cancellations amid weakened demand Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) CISA Integrated Operations Coordination Center (CIOCC) –
Physical 202-282-9201 ciocc@cisa.dhs.gov FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY Page 1 of 3 (TLP: GREEN)
FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY (TLP: GREEN)

Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Integrated Operations Division FOOD AND AGRICULTURE NJ issued a framework to assist in minimizing the spread of COVID-19 for farm workers throughout the agricultural production process.
A Seafood processing facility in Oregon laid off 500 employees due to 8 employees testing positive for COVID-19.
There are continued closures and idled production in meat processing facilities across the Midwest; the trend is slowly improving with closed plants reopening and beginning to resume production.
GOVERNMENT FACILITIES (Election Infrastructure)
CT Governor signed an order allowing residents to vote absentee in the 11 August primaries.
NM:
Secretary of State will hold the state’s General Election School virtually in August.
NY, IN, & DC:
Primary will be conducted on 2 June.
IN early voting locations opened Tuesday, one week before the primary election day, 2 June.
Qualified voters do not need to wear a mask, respect social distancing, use gloves, sanitize hands at any point in voting process, or have a temperature in 'normal' range.
DC:
The mayor announced voting centers for the Primary Election will be open through Election Day on 2 June.
HEALTHCARE AND PUBLIC HEALTH AL Governor announced a new health order that extends to 3 July and has changes subject to social distancing and sanitation rules and guidelines.
A second case of Multisystem Inflammatory Syndrome in Children (MIS-C) associated with COVID-19 has been confirmed by the Fairfax Health District.
The Ohio National Guard will begin testing all staff and certain residents within Ohio’s 960 nursing homes.
TRANSPORTATION SYSTEMS (Aviation)
The economic Impact of Coronavirus on U.S. Commercial Airports will now significantly set back U.S. airports from stable growth prospects.

A total loss of $23.3B is expected • COVID-19 has forced several airlines across the globe to restructure or cease operations The FAA issued an exemption that allows US airlines to carry cargo on seats in airplane cabins when no passengers are being transported TX Governor issued an Executive Order which terminates previous air travel restrictions which required temporary quarantines for air travelers arriving from several other states Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency (CISA) CISA Integrated Operations Coordination Center (CIOCC) –
Physical 202-282-9201 ciocc@cisa.dhs.gov FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY Page 2 of 3 (TLP: GREEN)
FOR OFFICIAL USE ONLY (TLP: GREEN)

Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency Integrated Operations Division (Freight Rail) Low volume of cargo shipments including oil and overseas goods are resulting in reduced railroad activity.
CSX and Canadian Pacific Railroads have instituted voluntary furloughs.
(Pipeline) Pipeline utilization is forecast to fall below 60% in 2021 ACTIVATIONS AND DECLARATIONS The ReOpen DC Advisory Group recommended that DC reopen in 4 stages.
Tentative reopen date would be 29 May, if DC continues downward trends, MI:
The governor’s executive order to reopen retail businesses and auto dealerships statewide takes effect on 26 May. MN:
A gradual return of youth sports will begin on 1 June.
NJ:
The governor issued an executive order allowing groups of 25 for gatherings and businesses (previously limited to 10) and opening campgrounds statewide.
NY:
The governor announced on 25 May that all NY professional sports leagues will be able to begin training camps.
The New York Stock Exchange starts a phased reopening of the trading floor Tuesday.
TX:
Restaurants may operate for dine-in service up to 50% occupancy Northern Virginia has met four of the six threshold metrics needed to transition to the first phase of reopening.
Those include having enough hospital beds and intensive care capacity and having a downward trend of positive tests and hospitalizations over a period of 14 days.
The region still has not met two important metrics: •
It does not have an increasing and sustainable supply of PPE, and it has not sufficiently increased testing and tracing to meet the established regional threshold.
WARNING:

** Hello County Partners, Meeting Dates 1.
Our next State-County meeting is scheduled for Thursday, June 25th, 2020.
Agenda is forthcoming.
Send agenda items to Bianca.Soto@azdhs.gov at least 1 week prior to the meeting.
Quarterly webinar meeting is scheduled for Wednesday, May 20th, 2020.
Click on the link below; navigate to the DAVE County Quarterly Webinar for registration information.
https://azdhs.gov/licensing/vital- records/index.php#dave-county Funeral Home Death 1.
New

** With the goals of ensuring we provide the National Center for Health Statistics with quality and Data Quality Report complete data including adhering to Arizona death registration time frames regarding statute and administrative – County Level st code, we are rolling out our 1 phase of data quality reports.
The attached reports represent the timeliness and completeness of death registrations for all funeral homes in your county.
The 2nd phase of data quality reports will focus on each facility.
These reports are forthcoming.
If you have any questions, please contact Bianca.Soto@azdhs.gov COVID-19 1.
Useful links for reference Informational Links https://azdhs.gov/index.php
https://emergency.cdc.gov/coca/calls/2020/callinfo_041620.asp 2.
New Video (3 minutes) Guidance for Certification of COVID-19 Deaths https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=oL3VMwieAms Important Links 1.
Electronic Version of the BVR Binder: https://drive.google.com/open?id=122H_m4i5s1pxxJItarHIgd- o4t0RjFOS
o This link contains the most current electronic version of all items that should be in your BVR Support Binder.
Birth Training Link: https://ebrs.azvitals.com/DocumentManagement/Home/GuestView?q=jJ6uFKGUJVVTbgBa2-2B-Nuhb0sKBgOPNbA
o This link contains all current Birth resources.
3.Death Training Link: https://ebrs.azvitals.com/DocumentManagement/Home/GuestView?q=jJ6uFKGUJVXgI6CRvxWxeFWAOEFNlzXE
o This link contains all current Death resources.
Fetal Death Training Link: https://ebrs.azvitals.com/DocumentManagement/Home/GuestView?q=jJ6uFKGUJVWhYnGMqHK0CAnst7c3R3jy
o This link contains all current Fetal Death resources.
DAVE Training webpage:
https://azdhs.gov/licensing/vital-records/index.php#dave-home
o This is a public facing web page that includes all resources created for all DAVE external partners.
NCHS Training Materials: https://www.cdc.gov/nchs/nvss/training-and-instructional-materials.htm
o This web page was created by the CDC and houses several Birth, Death and Fetal Death Training resources.
VitalChek Orders – 1.
Gentle reminder to those offices that process VitalChek orders in DAVE.
Offices include; BVR, Cochise, Reminder Maricopa and Pima.
Please ensure you are checking the Shipping Address Invalid Order Work queue.
Orders with a foreign mailing address may appear in this queue for your review and processing.
Standing Reminders 1.
All county offices are required to deposit any funds available to them in DAVE on a daily basis by processing their respective VitalChek Close Report.
Contact us CountySupport@azdhs.gov if you have any questions on how to do this - we're here to help you :) 2.
Do Not Share Passwords in any Vital Records Systems.
Contact us at CountySupport@azdhs.gov if you need your password reset.
Send all Security Paper Packing Slips for review and provisioning to Toni.Miller@azdhs.gov.
Refer to policy 009 Security Paper – Ordering, Receipt, and Handling for additional information.
All surrogacy and gender marker orders/changes must be submitted to the BVR for review.
All subpoenas must be forwarded to the BVR for review and response.
If possible, do not accept service of a subpoena and direct all subpoenas pertaining to vital records to CountySupport@azdhs.gov 5.
Vital records systems shall not be accessed outside of licensed facilities or offices.
Please email Bianca.Soto@azdhs.gov
and Toni.Miller@azdhs.gov if you are considering any changes to your vital records operational services.
This includes but is not limited to office location changes, office additions, fee changes, application changes, etc.
Thank you for all you do!
Thank you for your time.

Bianca Soto Educator & Quality Assurance Manager Arizona Department of Health Services 1818 West Adams Avenue, Phoenix, AZ 85007 Direct 602-364-1252 Email Bianca.Soto@azdhs.gov Health and Wellness for all Arizonans CONFIDENTIALITY NOTICE:

['Good morning Marilyn and Hoyt, My team asked the ombudsman for an update on the status of LTCFs in the area.
Here what we’ve told:
Facility Accepting New Admissions?
Bonnell
Yes, but extremely limited—only from independent and assisted living on Good Samaritan campus.
More TBD.
Centennial HCC Preparing to accept COVID patients (up to 10 now, max ~30).
At least a week away—currently accepting and cohorting COVID+ patients from Kenton Manor.
The Center @Centerplace Preparing for 2nd floor non-COVID unit (27 private rooms).
Reviewing plans now.
Columbine No—in current outbreak.
FairAcres Manor Preparing for non-COVID admissions—must have no new onset of illness x 14 days (on day 11).
Start slow but capacity ~30.
Grace Pointe No—recently had COVID + resident.
Holding for 14 days.
Kenton Manor No—current outbreak.
Positive residents being sent to Centennial until release from isolation and will return.
Life Care Center No—on hold; willing to accept non-COVID patients.
Have 2 suspect COVID residents; labs pending.
Windsor Health Care Yes--limited admissions of non-COVID patients only Center Does this all sync with your teams’ awareness of LTCFs in the region?
Are you in need of more LTCF beds to discharge COVID-19 positive patients ?
If so, about how many beds per week?

Thanks … Mark Mark E. Wallace, MD, MPH Executive Director and Chief Health Officer Department of Public Health & Environment 1555 N. 17th Avenue - Greeley, Colorado - 80631 Tele: 970.304.6410 - Fax: 970.304.6412 Web: http://www.weldhealth.org

Confidentiality Notice: This electronic transmission and any attached documents or other writings are intended only for the person or entity to which it is addressed and may contain information that is privileged, confidential or otherwise protected from disclosure.
If you have received this communication in error, please immediately notify sender by return e-mail and destroy the communication.
Any disclosure, copying, distribution or the taking of any action concerning the contents of this communication or any attachments by anyone other than the named recipient is strictly prohibited. ']
['Gary, I am trying to think COVID again!
But yes, our attention has been diverted, unfortunately.
Thanks for the kind words.
I think it would be helpful to have a quick call around what you’ve seen over this past week.
We haven’t talked about wanting to transition to yellow, and it sounds like things are sort of the same this week as last.
We’d love your perspective on it if you have 15 minutes tomorrow.
Thank you!
RACHEL OTTO Chief of Staff O: 801-535-7732 C: 801.835.8763 OFFICE of the MAYOR SALT LAKE CITY CORPORATION WWW.SLCMAYOR.COM WWW.SLC.GOV
From: Gary Edwards <GEdwards@slco.org
Date: Tuesday, June 2, 2020 at 3:04 PM
To: "Otto, Rachel" <Rachel.Otto@slcgov.com>
Subject: (EXTERNAL) COVID Rachel, I know you guys are not thinking COVID right now, but wanted to make sure I knew of any desire on the City’s part to transition to yellow.
In looking at zip codes 84104 and 84116, both seemed to peak the week of 4/26-5/2, 84116 much higher than 84104 (71 vs 44).
84104 has remained fairly stable since that time (from 44 to 38 cases per week) while 84116 has been fairly unpredictable (from 71 to 36 cases per week, with an increase seen over the last week).
Please let me know if you want to discuss, or what your desires might be when the Governor make announcements Thursday.
I also want to say how impressed I was with SLCPD and the other officers.
Thank you. ']
["Good morning Trish.
Our leadership team is in discussion on this.
As soon as we have a decision we will get in touch.
Thanks, Tyler From: Trish McClain <trishm@nchd.org>
Sent: Tuesday, April 21, 2020 8:22 AM
To: Chantelle Johnson <Chantelle_Johnson@cargill.com
Cc:
Tyler Luft <Tyler_Luft@cargill.com>
Subject: Re: Thanks for being on today's call [EXTERNAL]
This email came from outside of Cargill.
Do not click links or open attachments unless you recognize the sender.
If you suspect this is spam, send this email as an attachment to spam@cargill.com Good morning, I wanted to circle back to make sure I haven't missed anything.
Is it correct to say that at this time Cargill will not be pursuing a testing option for the Fort Morgan site?
Thanks and hope you both have a good day.
Trish On Wed, Apr 15, 2020 at 4:30 PM Chantelle Johnson <Chantelle_Johnson@cargill.com> wrote: No worries – it is a crazy busy time for all of us.
We did get the information we needed to share with our business.
Thanks again for all the help and your time.
Hang in there!

Chantelle Johnson RN/BSN/COHN/CM Occupational Health and Worker’s Comp Manager Cargill Protein Cargill Helping the world thrive direct: 316-291-2152 | mobile: 316-648-5237 Wichita KS | Chantelle_Johnson@cargill.com "]
entities: Occupational Health and Worker’s Comp Manager

content: ['Everyone, 1.
First: the email issue Brandon Smith mentioned on the call this morning is REAL.
If possible, please send an email organization-
wide to your staff because if they ever emailed me, or ever received an email from me, they most likely received that spam email.
It went out to everyone who has ever been in my email box.
It was very well done and the usual warning signs were not obvious.
If anyone received an email from me this morning – Delete!
Do not open!
If opened, get your IT staff on this right away.

Also, that spam attack created a process which deleted every incoming email sent to me; this was not fixed until IT staff reset everything (deactivated my account, scanned computer for viruses, established new password, set up 2-step authentication).
For that reason, would you please respond to this email so I can confirm receipt?
I will reach out by phone to those who don’t respond to make sure all are aware of this. 2.
Attached please find a PDF version of the press announcement released by the Treasurer-Tax Collector, to extend the deadline for property tax payments to May 4, 2020.
Jordan Kaufman asked me to share with all of you that the county has taken the necessary steps to ensure there is enough liquidity in the Treasury Pool to withstand this extension.
If you sent me an email this morning to advise of a point of contact to receive information from Public Health on noncompliant businesses, I did not receive it.
The only response I’ve received so far is from California City.
Thanks, Geo Georgianna Armstrong Kern County Office of Emergency Services 2601 Panorama Drive, Building B, Bakersfield, CA 93306
entities: Kern County Office of Emergency Services

['Good afternoon, Attached is the daily report of COVID-19 outbreak statistics for long term care facilities.
Today’s count is 468 facilities with one or more COVID-19 positive residents and/or staff.
Additional statistics: 6,746 COVID-19 Positive Residents (cumulative) 4,002 Residents Recovered from COVID-19 1,214 Resident Deaths 3,021 COVID-19 Positive Staff (cumulative)
Testing: 81.7% of residents tested 63.8% of staff tested For Nursing Homes, specifically: Testing numbers are 100% of residents tested and 73% of staff tested.

Best Regards, Melanie Melanie Simon Executive Director, Healthcare Facility Regulation Georgia Department of Community Health 2 Peachtree Street, N.W., Suite 31-403 Atlanta, GA 30303 (404) 657-3990 msimon@dch.ga.gov To schedule meetings, please contact Renee Peoples at renee.peoples@dch.ga.gov.
Follow us on Twitter at http://twitter.com/gadch and Facebook at https://www.facebook.com/gadept/communityhealth.
Reader Advisory Notice: Email to and from a Georgia state agency is generally public record, except for content that is confidential under specific laws.

[' CAUTION:
This email originated from an External Source.
Please use caution before opening attachments, clicking links, or responding to this email.
Do not sign-in with your City of Las Vegas account credentials.

U.S. DEPARTMENT OF HOMELAND SECURITY Intergovernmental Affairs Please see the advisory below from our partners in the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) regarding an update on the Whole-of-America response to COVID-19.

April 11, 2020 FEMA Advisory Coronavirus (COVID-19) Pandemic Whole-of-America Response Attached you will find today’s FEMA Daily Briefing Points and a Reference Document for Messaging and Resource Links for the Whole-of-America response to coronavirus (COVID-19) pandemic.
These briefing points include Topline Messages, as well as By the Numbers; FEMA and Department of Health and Human Services Response; and Guidance from Federal Agencies.
entities: Department of Health and Human Services

content: Topline messaging includes: • FEMA, HHS, and our federal partners work with state, local, tribal and territorial governments to execute a whole- of-America response to COVID-19 pandemic and protect the health and safety of the American people.

FEMA continues to expedite movement of commercially pre-sourced and commercially procured critical supplies from the global market to medical distributors in various locations across the U.S. through Project Air Bridge.
Data and information-sharing are critical for moving forward in this response and equipping areas expected to be the next medical hot spots.

Considering both scarcity of ventilators in the Strategic National Stockpile (SNS) and current capacity of the private sector to meet demand, the federal government has adopted a process to manage allocation of federal ventilator resources to ensure the right amount of ventilators are shipped to the to the right states to sustain life within a 72-hour window.

○ Emergency managers and public health officials submit requests for ventilators to FEMA/HHS, providing detailed data on total medical/ hospital beds; total acute care (ICU) beds; normal occupancy; predicted surge occupancy; and number of ventilators available in the state.

○ States can send requests outside of the 72-hour window for consideration by the federal government; allocation decisions and/or shipments, however, should not be expected until the state is within the immediate 72-hour window.
Hospital administrators across the country are being asked to provide daily reports on testing, capacity, supplies, utilization, and patient flows to facilitate the ongoing public health response.

On April 10, HHS Secretary Azar sent a follow up letter to hospital administrators, reinforcing the need for this data to be provided daily to facilitate planning, monitoring, and resource allocation in response to COVID- 19.
Our objective is to allow states and hospitals either to leverage existing data reporting capabilities or, where those capabilities are insufficient, to provide guidance in how to build on them.

The letter included a set of frequently asked questions that details federal government’s data needs, explains the division of reporting responsibility between hospitals and states, and provides clear, flexible options for the timely delivery of this critical information.
These FAQs will be updated if additional data delivery methods become available.

The letter also recognizes that many non-Federal entities may already be requesting this information from hospitals; therefore, the federal government has done its best to minimize the burden of sharing this data and to reduce further duplication of effort.

On April 10, HHS began delivering the initial $30 billion in relief funding to providers in support of the national response to COVID-19, with $26 of the $30 billion expected to be delivered to providers’ bank accounts the same day.
The payments are part of the distribution of the $100 billion provider relief fund included in the CARES Act.
To expedite providers getting money as quickly as possible, the initial funding was distributed immediately proportionate to providers’ share of Medicare fee-for-service reimbursements in 2019.

The Administration is rapidly working on future targeted distributions to hospitals and providers that will focus on providers in areas particularly impacted by COVID-19, rural providers, and providers with lower shares of Medicare reimbursement or who predominantly serve the Medicaid population.
On April 8, HHS announced the first contract for ventilator production rated under the Defense Production Act, to General Motors.
A second contract was awarded to Philips on the same day for ventilator production.

The Philips contract was for $646.7 million for the delivery of 2,500 ventilators to the Strategic National Stockpile by the end of May 2020 and a total of 43,000 ventilators to be delivered by the end of December 2020.

○ GM’s contract, at a total contract price of $489.4 million, is for 30,000 ventilators to be delivered to the Strategic National Stockpile by the end of August, with a production schedule allowing for the delivery of 6,132 ventilators by June 1. •

On April 3, President Trump issued “Memorandum on Allocating Certain Scarce or Threatened Health and Medical Resources to Domestic Use” directing DHS and FEMA, in consultation with the HHS, to use the Defense Production Act to keep scarce medical resources within the United States for domestic use.
CBP is assisting FEMA in temporarily detaining export shipments of PPE.
PPE subject to this policy includes: N95 respirators, and a variety of other respirators; surgical masks; and, surgical gloves.
Follow Us Follow FEMA on social media at: FEMA online, on Twitter @FEMA or @FEMAEspanol, on FEMA Facebook page or FEMA Espanol page and at FEMA YouTube channel.
Also, follow Administrator Pete Gaynor on Twitter @FEMA_Pete.
FEMA Mission To help people before, during and after disasters.

['Hi Fred.
Sorry for the delay, still catching up.
Although July 4th seems like a ways off and there seems to be some talk about eventually relaxing some of the recommendations I’m uncertain about the timing.
As you are likely aware our case count continues to rise the and number of new cases per day seems to be increasing.
As we get closer to July 4th we can continue to discuss and explore options.
- Matt From: Frederick Clark <fclark@farmersagent.com>
Sent: Thursday, April 16, 2020 10:04 AM
To: Matt Constantine <matt@kerncounty.com>
Subject: Kern River Valley Chamber of Commerce CAUTION:
entities: Kern River Valley Chamber of Commerce

content: This email originated from outside of the organization.
Do not click links, open attachments, or provide information unless you recognize the sender and know the content is safe.
Good morning
Matthew, I hope you and your team are holding up well with the daily flood of questions your team has to deal with.
I need a crystal ball moment if possible, The Chamber is preparing for July 4, 2020 mentally
but I need your "opinion".
Do you feel we will be allowed to have the July 4, 2020 fireworks display over Isabella Lake?
I personally do not see a stand down on the social distancing guidelines anytime in the near future
but I do not have your team to tell me I am correct or incorrect.
My concern is simple, when we hold this event the shoreline and parking lots around this lake are a massive tailgate party which clearly is not a 6' space issue.
I am not the guy who wishes to be the barer of bad news but we also need to be realistic as we deal with this virus.
Thank you for your time and your thoughts on the issue, your information will just allow myself and the board to decide what needs to take place for this years event.

Stay safe, Frederick Clark Farmers Insurance 6416 Lake Isabella Blvd Ste B Lake Isabella, CA 93240-9475 License Number: 0L04825 760-379-5641 (Office) 760-812-7318 (Mobile) 760-608-8107 (Fax) fclark@farmersagent.com http://www.farmersagent.com/fclark ']

["Hi All, There are a few INCREDIBLY key pieces of information in Justin's initial email that are missing.
Early on in the pandemic, public health officials advised growers AGAINST mass testing of asymptomatic folks.
Why?
a. We had low testing capacity in the gorge and asymptomatic testing was not part of CDC or public health recommendations at this time.
Even growers who were considering mass testing backed off of this concept after discussions with local public health.
b.
Are we mass testing asymptomatic employees in other industries?
I haven't needed a test to work in my laboratory at the community college.
Forcing testing on a certain population seems like a potential civil rights issue to me.
Growers are most concerned with THIS liability.
c. I NEVER SAID GROWERS DID NOT WANT
TESTING!!!!\u200b
This is completely false.
Growers want testing for sick folks just like everyone else in the US.
They are leery of mass testing given the discussions with public health.
Growers have several unfounded fears around testing and on farm education: 1.
Some growers feel like they have no right to ask folks to submit to a medical training or testing.
They fear that they are liable because this is seen as medical advice and they are not medical personnel.
I am not happy with this response but I can understand their general fear about repercussions if someone does fall ill after a training.
Some growers think mass testing is a HIPPA issue.
It's not!
Someone with authority should step up and explain why.
Some growers are fearful of agencies and their workers are also fearful of agencies.
The US doesn't have a great track record with agencies and minority folks.
Writing this next bit goes against my better judgment, but over the past several days I have been absolutely disgusted with some people's preconceived notions of the folks I work along side.
Growers are not idiots and they are certainly not a group of folks actively engaged in human rights abuses.
They recognize the need for a healthy work force.
Healthy and well treated workers are needed to harvest fruit.
In addition, 99% of them are caring human beings like the general population.
They don't want to see people get sick.
They want to test sick folks.
Don't believe me?
Look at the number of reports from The Dalles.
Tenneson's have taken an absolute beating from local organizations, but let me tell you this: The moment Hailey realized someone on the farm wasn't feeling well
she called me to find out exactly what to do.
After our discussion, she immediately phoned public health and MCMC.
Everyone is doing there best in a time of fear and chaos.
Sincerely, Ashley Ashley A. Thompson PhD "]

Subject: RE: Fall Opening Help Pam, I addressed all of this with Michael, David and Joe on Friday and Michael indicated that he was planning to address this item at the AVP meeting today.
Specific to student staff training, although most of the training has been shifted to a virtual environment, I will need to engage some level of in- person training prior to reopening.
Regardless of the opening date, I will need access time to train our staff as our operation has changed considerably.
We have developed a plan to train our staff in small groups and would certainly adhere to all appropriate guidelines, but yes, Pam, I agree, there are many details to explore further.
Cyndi Cynthia Costanzo Executive Director | UConn Recreation 2060 Hillside Road U-1273 Storrs, CT 06269 Office: 860.486.2264 | Fax: 860.486.5064

["Joy, great question.
We have, as you saw last week, issued guidance for scheduling course for the Spring, but I don't know how far other planning is at this point.
Let's submit this to our COVIDgroup.
From:Joy B. Landeira <jlandeir@uwyo.edu>
Sent: Monday, September 7, 2020 1:56 PM
To: Anne M. Alexander <AAlex@uwyo.edu>
Subject: plan for next semester WLD events?
Hi Anne, This is the time that our department begins planning for our annual World Language Day, normally held the first weekend of March.
We held it in 2020 the week before spring break, and it was the largest event ever, over 400 participants from Wyo middle schools and high schools, plus their teachers and chaperones.
We were so fortunate to host that many folks on campus without any issues just as the Corona Virus outbreak and the shutdown were happening.
I am writing now for your advice about what to do for March 2021.
Do you anticipate that we will be able to host such a huge event in March 2021?
Shall we try to do it virtually instead of in person?
I can't foresee what UW's policy will be, and I don't know if you have made a policy yet for next semester.
I would appreciate your input before we try to organize an on-campus event for next semester.
Thank you, Joy Landeira Dept Head, Modern and Classical Languages 55 "]

['Hi Marc, No problem.
I can set time to call our FLC list Monday when I am in office.
We had immediate and really good reception when Amy and I made the calls earlier this week for the masks.\xa0\xa0
Amy
and I contacted north county FLC earlier in the week.
I will query CalAg today for 2020 registrants county wide and work with Amy and Oscar to make these calls.
Best, Jodie Snowbarger Agricultural Inspector/Biologist III (p) 805-434-4898 (f) 805-781-1035 jeckard@co.slo.ca.us www.slocounty.ca.gov From: Marc Lea <mlea@co.slo.ca.us>
Sent: Friday, June 5, 2020 9:38 AM
To: Amy Breschini <abreschini@co.slo.ca.us>; Oscar Morales <omorales@co.slo.ca.us>; Jodie Snowbarger <jSnowbarger@co.slo.ca.us>
Cc:

Tom B. Morgan <tbmorgan@co.slo.ca.us> Subject: I need your assistance with a COVID related farm worker project Amy, Jodie, and Oscar, Tom M. mentioned that Amy and Jodie had recently reached out to the FLC's in the county to let them know about the non-surgical masks that we have available for distribution.
I've got another COVID related project going on regarding access to testing and access to separate shelter for anyone who tests positive for COVID.
The County is really looking for input from local growers and FLC's, and since you have reached out to the FLC's recently I'd like your assistance on reaching out to them on these new topics.
Here's the questions that we need feedback on: 1.
Do your employees know that they can get a free COVID test at any Community Health Center in SLO County? 2.
Would your employees be more likely to get tested if the County ran a free "pop-up" testing site at a local farm or vineyard on a pre-arranged day?
If the answer is yes, do you have any ideas on a good location to hold that kind of testing event?
If one of your employees contracts COVID, have you already made arrangements for a place that they can stay that is separated from their co-workers?

REGARDLESS OF THEIR ANSWER TO THIS QUESTION, PLEASE LET THEM KNOW THAT THE COUNTY HAS MADE ARRANGEMENTS FOR UTILIZING LOCAL HOTEL ROOMS AS A TEMPORARY SHELTER FOR ANY FARM WORKER WHO'S CONTRACTED COVID AND NEEDS A SEPARATE PLACE TO STAY.
WE ARE STILL WORKING OUT THE DETAILS ON PAYMENT
(e.g. does the County or Employer pay),
BUT THE PROCESS ITSELF IS ALREADY AVAILABLE
IF THAT IS EVER NEEDED.
It's not that important that we speak to every single FLC.
It's more important that we talk to as many of them as we can in a short period of time.
If at all possible, we could use some feedback by next Tuesday from 10-20 FLC's.
If any of them have questions that you can't answer, you are welcome to direct them to me.
Also, if anyone does express an interest in the "pop-up" testing site, please let me know
and I will follow up with them myself.
If there's a demand for one of those testing sites, I'm going to try and help Public Health facilitate those arrangements.
The County is working on a one-page brochure that explains some of this stuff.
It's almost ready.
As soon as it's cleared for distribution, I'll be sending you those PDFs in English and Spanish.
So you can assume that will be ready in the next day or so, and that you will be able to follow up with the FLC via email and send them the PDFs - so please check that we have their email on file.
Lastly, since you called the FLC's recently, it's probably easiest to have Amy and Jodie work out who is going to call who.
If you need additional assistance, or there is an FLC owner who is primarily Spanish speaking, please utilize Oscar's help.
If you're swamped on time and really aren't able to make any calls today, Monday, or Tuesday, please let me know
and I'll find another staff person who is available.

thanks so much for your help on this project, Marc\xa0\xa0 Marc Lea, Assistant Agricultural Commissioner/Sealer Department of Agriculture / Weights & Measures (p) 805-781-5907 | (f) 805-781-1035 mlea@co.slo.ca.us | http://www.slocounty.ca.gov/agcomm.htm ']
